element_texts.text:
5-947
_____
Department of the Interior,
U.S. Indian Service.

John T. Frader
U.S. Indian Agent.

Ayer
Gift 1967
Prof. Robert Ihrmann
Beloit College

1907 
Oct 9 Gon-dway-way an old Indian Woman was struck by an Engine at the Otockansock Depot while in an intoxicated condition from which injury she died. Having been brought by the some train to Walkus Hospital and Cared for by Dr. F. L. Wilcox who notified Dr. L.M. Hosdin Supt.? Physician who examined the patient in consultation with Dr. Wilcox.
Devitt. C. Hayes Started for Chicago Ill this A.M. on Leave.
The L. L. school being entirely out of fuel at request of Dr Hardin. The agency has loaned the school 10Cords? Wood. Same to be replaced out of Wood when purchased for the school. 
underlined This to keep the school open.underline

1907
Oct 15 Dr. Radwell accepts Supt'cy of Vermilion Lake school @1400.00 to perform all duties with competence clark 60 days @ 3.00 per day. 
Wise? to Com-Indian affairs.
Oats quoted @ 59 c. f.o.b. Wallace 
?Aette buy or 57 c.
Coal arriving for L. L. School via gt. wo. ry. instead of M&L. as we wer advised & had been ordered. Weather fine this day.
Oct 19 4 Cars coal still on track at Walker. Our ?cart unloaded in Coal House at school. one in New Stand.
Bemidji Elevator Co. ?oats 58c bid 57 1/2. If last figure accepted to ship. If not to call office by telephone.
Notified Indians annuity payment would be made at agency office 25th 26th. Police to notify Indians.
(Margins) Notice to C&W and ROP through Radwell. Caswell & Warren

1907 Oct 21 Nothing special. Delivery of coal continued. Oct 22  D.C. Hayes & Wife returned from Chicago this P.M. Also the newly appointed ?matron for the L.L. School arrived over Gt. No. this P.M. Still unloading coal for school. Oct 23 Jim Natrum - an Indian charged with assault & Rape of an old Indian woman. taken to the County Jail by Dept. Sheriff McCabe. Oct. 25 Annuity payment today. Agency Indians & Land tokens. 29 Cass Lake & Bonn. Dr Hardin off on leave. 30 Ball club & Duluth. 31 McGreggor

1907
Nov 4 No Land sales . no bids. Weather fine. Steamboat leaking. out of water for repairs.
Nov 5 Dr. Wilcox called to examine and treat the school boy Willie Ryan. Prescribed for him and gave the opinion that it was not necessary to discharge the boy from school. Chingo requested to be allowed to take his little girl We-o-gah-bow out of school on account of a severe cough. To be investigated. Francis Partridge 8.89 ((ah mah je way qwy? ))
Peter Pardridge 8.89 ((Oizho e ge shig?))
To Miss Alice Pendergast Teacher in charge for their benefit at ((skin drums?)) wise
Nov 6 Mrs Carson of Bemidji ((unclear)) drew all her funds. Only routine business.

Nov 12 Joe Weaver requested that his little girl Sarah Weaver be sent home for a few days to wait on her mother who is sick on account of a birth in her family. ((underlined)) granted ((underlined)). to be returned soon as the mother can be up.

1907 
Nov 14 Dr. Wilcox called a/c sick girl at school. Failed to get over. 
" 15 Dr. Wilcox boat over in agency steamboat to see Indian children at school and the Matron Miss Roessler.
Acquired ((blank)) lbs hay and as there was more action to be had took balance of car loan from J.A ((unclear)) through ((?Mes ?Brainerd & Kulandin)), Price per Jan, fortunate to get the hay. got information from A. Lavigne as to cost of foot bridge across swamp at Sugarpoint.
Requested Dr. Wilcox to come over on morning of 16th to see Joe ((?Newsoms)) wife. Blood poisoning feared - following child birth.
Collected $5.00 from Jim Natum for materials furnished for funeral of his wife by Frank Colome and paid same to C. Bilbin to cover the account. 11/16/07

11/15 Paid George Bonyet 3400
Jim Natum 7.70 + 5.00 F Colome 1270
Paid George Weavers bill to C.E.G & Co.
$5.50 P.O Money order to him for ((?bal)) 85c.
Nov 18 Ben White reports that his brother Wm White or Ah-go-bit was found frozen to death Saturday north of Longville. He had evidently broken through the ice and being wet and chilled had been unable to start a fire which he had apparently tried to do. Whether this death is due to whisky or accident is not explained. but it being the third death in that locality recently two of which are reported to be from that cause it would appear to be time for the county authorities and pure food authorities to see what sort of stuff is being dispensed to Indians & lumberjacks of that locality

1907
Nov 19 The ice fully 1 inch on the bay and broke track out to canal. took gorge to Walker for car fuel. returned some to poplar dock. to be unloaded from there 20000 lbs to school 18000 lbs to agency. Pulled the steam boat out of the water for the winter. Had to saw out ice at the landing. 4 inch ice for 75ft from shore.
((underlined)) Last trip of the steamer for 1907 ((underlined))

1907
Nov 21 Received 9000lbs corn at Walker through ?Brainerd & Kulandin and same stored with them until some can be hauled across the lake on the ice. Receited for same so they can draw for the price @ 70c 112.50 9 sks @ 10c 9.00 
Tot. 121.50
22 Chimneys on Shoemakers house are completed. One pupil from the school reported as a run away - by name Joe Hayes. reported to police. Weather fine.
23 The boy Joe Hayes reported as having returned in the evening after a visit to his mother without leave. Police notified.

11/29 Crossed the Lake with mail Carrier in thin and slush ice to make trip to Cass Lake to confer with Dr. Radwell as to his medical supply report and the delivery of the property before proceeding to Vermilion Lake School Mines. He will have his ((expeditions?)) noted and leave all securely locked. ((unclear)) to be locked up in the warehouse, Key to be available to the ((unclear)) Tandy the Black Smith to look after the property.
11/30 Returned home from Cass Lake this A.M. Lake open but rough.

12/2 Our mail service reduced to one mail daily. Serving ((Omijun?)) office at 3.30 P.M. A bad arrangement for the agency. B.W. Clark returned from his vacation.
12/3 Bad crossing lake on account of ice - Dr. L.M Hardin & family returned from vacation and crossed with mail carried & B.W Clark to the agency.
12/4 Lake almost closed. Impossible to cross. No mail today
12/5 Mail carrier crossed in row boat but could not return and crossed with some Indians on the ice lower down the lake. reached the office at 8.10 P.M

12/7 Received a letter from ((?Lt.)) N. Warren Prime in charge of Bena stating that there were two cases of small pox in Bena and that he had three cases in the school that the Doctor calling from Cass Lake thought would develop smallpox. Telegraphed him to employ Doctor to vaccinate the school children and quarantine the school rigidly - his letter dated the 6th did not reach the office until evening of the 7th
12/9 Wrote Dr. Smith of Oaklahoma City to hurry his assumption of the position of Agency Physician at Cass Lake on account of possible epidemic of small pox.

12/11 No further word from Bena as to health conditions. Have warned Benj. Caswell Prime in charge of Cass Lake to look well after his school and keep them away from others as much as possible.
12/12 Have requested and accepted the resignation of John Sedean as Police Captain for the good of the service. The police are dissatisfied with his conduct in connection with the arrest of his Bro. Chas. Fairbanks. Good discipline required his withdrawal from the force.

1907
12/13 Ah-nah-we-ay-gah-bow with his two sons wants to cut cord wood for the agency. Will pay them $1.50 for cord and scale up and pay them at the end of each week so they can live. They are to cut to white pine and are to leave the butts of every trees that will make saw logs and may cut oak & popple.

1907
Dec 24 In company with Peter Groves I visited Surgarpoint and after a careful view of the School House location and site examined the shore line and measured same across the bay between the day school site and ((?Pug ah we ge shigs)) point and found that a walk 156 rods or 2574 ft. would cover the beach line route. the walk to be places about 20ft from the water line as we found it which is now about 1 foot lower than on a full head. On a straight line across the bay to touch the beach line and meet dry land on each side of the bay 134 rods or 2244 ft. This line would require one row of piling and would have to be done in the winter as piling woulc only be driven while the bay is frozen. The beach line walk can be built

1907 Sugar Point Causeway
12/24 in the summer and two lines of fence posts will answer in place of piling and will answer just as well and at much less expense. This can be made of 2 inch plank laid cross beams of 2x6 spiked to the fence posts which if set deep will make a substantial walk. If the shorter line is adopted using a single row of piling the cross beams would have to be of 3x8 spiked to both sides of each pile and would have to be done in winder complete.
1st Walk 2574 ft in length on beach line 644 posts 7' in length set 3 ft deep on the land. Cross beams each side spiked on 2" x 6" - 4'
((In margin)) Spikes 303# 30d ((In margin))
644 pieces = 2576'  = (322 ?bents)
200# 20d 483  Ps 2x12 - 16 = 15456' plank
33 1/3# 20d 161  Ps 2x4 - 16 = 1717

((underlined)) Sugar Point Causeway ((underlined))
12/27 2nd walk 2244' in length straight. Would require piling single row 2000'. 244' ends use posts same as on the beach line
250 piling 10' to 20'
62 posts 6'
500 Ps. 3" x 8" - 3 1/2 = 3500'
124 Ps. 2 x 6 - 4 = 496'
375 Ps 2 x 12 - 16 = 12000'
141 Ps 2 x 4 - 16 = 1504'
250 Ps 2 x 4 - 3 = 500
18000

1907
12/27 Dr. W.H Smith appointed Agency Physician arrived at Walker 12/26 at the agency this date. Sworn in to office. Went to Cass Lake and installed him as Physician in charge. C.M Tandy delivered the Door Keys to the Doctor. Same having been left in his care by Dr. J.J Radwell on his departure from the Vermilion Lake School.
12/31 Went to Cass Lake to transfer school propt. Took Dr. Smiths trunk from M & I, Sta to Cass Lake. A.C. of the Doctor

1908
Jan 1 Met Benj. Caswell of Walker at 8o'clock A.M proceeded to the boarding school and took his receipts for school property. Returned to Cass Lake and at 1.05 P.M proceeded to Bena and transferred the school propt. to H.W. Warren taking his receipts as Supt. & S. D Ayle, both Supts. wired the Supt. and assumed charge. Receipts covered all to close of business Dec 31-07. Learned at Bena that an Indian at Sugarpoint had been killed with a club but could get no particulars.
1/2 Arrived home at Agency at 9.30 A.M. Found that the New Years had passed off with rather less drunkenness than on the preceding New Years, only 19 locked up for drunkenness.

1/2/08 Nay-may-we-we-we appeared at the office and stated that the murder was committed at the house of Shaw-wom-o-say, by Mays-quen-e-quay who used a stick of wood used as a poker. that he jabbed the murdered man with the end of the stick and kicked his body furiously. That he took the stick from him and compelled him to desist, but the man died. The murdered man was May-Ihuck-e-way-we-dung. His wife, Ke-Ihubanice witnessed the murder of her husband and O-wah-way-nub-epe wife of Shaw-wom-o-say was present and witnessed the assault. The killing occurred in his house. The case was reported to the county atty. at Walker at once and he stated that a warrant would be issued for arrest of the boy

1/2/08 Mays-quon-e-quay. The witness Nay-may-we-we-we with John ((?Smith)) brother of the murdered man were advised to go to Walker and give the authorities all the information they had.?
1/3/08 Sent Police Captain John Bedean and Policemen Ben King & John La Mont to Sugarpoint at the request of Sheriff Robt. De ((?Lery)). They found Mays-quon-e-quay and placed him in the hands of Sherriff ((De Lery?)) - no trouble.
1/4/08 Attended Coroners inquest at Walker. Heard the testimony and am of the opinion that no murder was committed or attempted. May Ihuc e way we dung evidently was dead when his body was assaulted by the drunken boy. The autopsy disclosed a condition of the lungs that evidently caused death. And as he had been

Continued
1/4/08 at Bena that day and had been drinking, his condition was greatly aggravated and no doubt hastened his death. I am informed that the Coroners Jury found no evidence of murder and the boy Mays quen e quay. The end of another chapter on whisky among Indians. It ought to be a states prison offense to sell and Indian or to give an Indian a bottle or jug of whisky. If he had to go up to the bar and drink he could only do so while there - he could not carry any away with him.

1908
Jan 10 A council of the Pillager Chiefs was held in the police barracks to discuss matters considered of interest to them and particularly as to the employment of an attorney at Washington and also at Walker. They discussed the matter among themselves and had nearly all the talk interpreted so the Agent and Atty. Daniel ((?DeLery?)) whom they had invited to be present could know how they felt about the matter. They decided to request permission to send a delegation to Washington to present the matter to the Dept. and appointed as their delegates for the L. L reservation Red Blanket or Kay-gway-je-way-bin-ung and Geo. Burnette or Ne-be-dug-ah-nod-guod and for interpreter Simon Bonga. It was agreed that the C&W Indians be invited to appoint a delegate from each reservation making four delegates 5 in all with the interpreter.

1908
Jan 11 With Inspector of scaling ((unclear)) on allotment timber, surveyed the church and parsonage lots at the old Agency and also a site for a day-school. Will complete the survey of the Episcopal Cemetery and Catholic Church and parsonage lots at a future date - all located in Sec. 17-142-30
1/13 Commenced the cutting of ice and filling of ice houses.

1/26/08 ((underlined)) Teamster Drunk ((underlined)). Joe Osscar placed in charge of teams and barns until New Farmer puts in an appearance. The Teamsters to be on hand for work promptly on time in the morning and under no circumstance without express permission as a government team to be taken out of the barn at night by an Indian.

1908
Feb 4 In company with Joe Osscar ((?Engr)) visited Sugarpoint to inspect the location for a causeway wand locate a place where piling can be processed and the distance to haul same. Can get cedat about 1 1/2 mile home. Will have to take tents for camp for both horses & men. Also inspected the House built for Kay-mu-wun-aush the old Sugarpoint chief and settled with Mr. E.E Wold for the labor on ((?service)). $160.00 in full.
2/5 Snow commenced following evening of the 4th ((unclear)) and continued throughout the night and all this day making a fall of about one foot. The first heavy fall of this winter will make it bad getting the causeway built at Sugarpoint.

1908
Feb 7 J.B Noble - Agency Carpenter sick with apparent "Lagrippe"off duty and in bed.
10 Heavy fog, snow melting, almost rain
11 Snow very soft rain during the night having melted it rapidly. bad for logging roads.
12 Agency Carpenter ((?decided)) to make two strong  dining tables 3'x 10'. heavy legs, frames & top.

1908 Continued
Feb 14 The land lying in a free slope to the south with a good chance for a boat landing and being fairly central in the Indian settlement of that po... and contains 32.35 acres. will recommend that the entire lot be set off for purpose of the Day School and that the Indians whose homes are located on same be allowed to remain undisturbed. There are only three allotments on this section viz. Lot 2. ((? Chm Charrette)) Lot 3 John Barratt & Sos. of Chief Kah-kah-kim. There are 11 families that may be accommodated by the placing of the day school, as follows.
Ojib-waince Sec 24-143-31
Mah-che-wah-gah-quok " 18-"-30
Way-zhow-ush-quok-je-ush "7-"-
Chief
By-ah-be-dway-we-dung "23-"-31
Ah-nah-quod "23-"-"
Nu-Sug " 23-"-"
Day-dug-wok-be-duay "23-"-"

Continued
2/14 Ay-we-woush Sec 26-143-31
We-kainec " 26 " "
(Geo Stump) Mun Sise-ah-gerlug " 14 " " 
Kay-bay-ah-bun-duig " 18 " 30
Kay-bay-cumig ish-kung " 26 " 31
Nauzhah-o-say " 23 " "
Mayn-way-we-dung " 26 " "
2/17 J.F Bartlett advises the office that he has been called to Minneapolis on account of his wife's sickness.

2/25 Joe Osscar home from Sugarpoint with Pile driver & crew.
3/12 Joe Osscar reports that he has about 150 logs landed. Snow soft and roads useless for logging operations.
3/13 One case of smallpox reported this A.M. That of an Indian woman who recently came here from Cass Lake. This case is in the house of ((?Anje Cote)) in the village. Dr. Hardin Supt Physician investigated and pronounced it a genuine case of smallpox, vaccinated three children found there an ordered strict quarantine - also vaccinated a number of Indian children.

1908
Mar 16 Rufus Blakeley wants lumber for a House. 16 x 22. 1 1/2 story. 

  To have lumber soon as possible, will get sawed and if rafter can tow to his landing on East Side Ottertail point above old village.

3/19/08 Dr. Smith reports new cases of small pox on Cass River and up in the bowstring. Directed to look after some. Cont. advised after and instructed. asked as to supplies and clothing.
3/23 A drunken row reported from Sugarpoint. Police sent over to get party charged with assault and to learn facts. A blind pig reported just outside the reservation line on bay River - Sheriff should get the party.

4/3/08 Ah-wish-to-yah. A policeman acknowledged that he was drunk Apl 1-1908 - ((underlined)) all fools day ((end underline)). He signs an agreement not to indulge again for three months at Leech. He is permitted to continue on ((unclear)).
4/3/08 Charly Monroe. A policeman got drunk. He acknowledged his offence and asks that he be given a chance to make good pledging his word of honor to keep sober and attend to his duties. 
Both of the above are granted.

4/16/08 Sent B.W Clark to Walker for Dynamite and Caps to blow out ice which was crowding out the dock piling. Procured 20 sticks and caps cost $300. used part and saved both agency docks for the time being.
4/21/08 The ice went out of the bay and broke on the lake toward Walker so boats could land at Wrights point very early. Still much ice in the big Lake.
4/22 Crossed to Walker with Joe Osscar and Mr. Walter in Joe's little Indian boat, landed on Wright's point. Much smoke. Many woods fires.
4/24/08 First thunder of the season and rain all forenoon. Putting out forest fires. A most timely downpour.

4/30/08 J. R. Farr General unclear of Logging here today. Inquiry as to all unclear business unclear.
5/  
5/2/08  Wilber T. Elliot. Special agent arrived at Walker and crossed to the Agency with the Agent in the unclear with Mr. Kulander - The agent is much pleased to have him come as the New System of accounting is just being installed and the need of a board of unclear & condemnation is greatly needed. 
I have just learned that a young man -- Fred Finn has just returned from the Riggs Institute. his term having sufficed.

5/7/08 Painters Straight & Morritz  Commenced Painting buildings today.
5/12 Asst Supt Caldwell here for field unclear Town 146-147-148 R? 26-27-28. Conferenced past - and took Vol. 3 with him to Cass Lake to be copied and returned by Supt. ONeil.

5/14/08 David Shermolear proceeds to St Louis on order from Comdr Indian Affairs to inspect samples shown on proposals for furnishing supplies for year 1909 unclear ahead to ensure crossing the Lake, 
5/18/08 Ice Company with J.F. Engoldt & Jim Ortcar I visited the old agency, and find that the old school house is entirely worthless. The old office can be reframed and made unclear fair school house. The Smith Dwelling can be improved and made to answer for Employees Cottage at measurable cost and soon many new structures. 
5/28/08 Julius H. Brown - recently appointed Chuck Scalas of unclear Indian tribes consented for work and furnished unclear & Supplies and assigned to standard Sun Camps East of CasRoke.

6/2/08 Ed Warren called at the office today.

    P. Kennedy's Son Roy buried at Walker Minn. Died Sunday 5/31

6/3/08 Visited Cass Lake Sub Agency. 6/4 west to Bull Club. Met by appointment Chiefs Kah-de-way, Ogu mah woub.
They want an additional 80 acres of land allotted their people and unclear that Congress be requested to take the matter up at once. Also want the logs secured from the Ball Club Town site for their benefit.

    Want the agent to purpose the petitions and bring to a Council at Ball Club in September - want sufficient notice so all the N.O.P. band can be notified.

1908
Aug 11 Met Chuck Scalars at Cass Lake. Mrs. P. Kennedy and E.J. Frellire whom I heard designated to represent this office in the examination of lands unclear reservations under my charge. Also unclear Field agent S.J. Coulter under whose direction the examination is being made. He is sending out two Crows of two men each. The state has its representations with any man with each crow will make four more. They are to live a Cook & Camp man for each crew and the experience to be borne equally and unclear unclear for experience incurred. They will be furnished with unclear blankets by the field agent. and copy will be made of each days work and mailed to this office as often as they have opportunity. - A record book to be kept by each and when work is completed to be filed in this office. Having no others qualified to do the work and

8/11/08 at this time of the year the Ck. Scales are more nearly at liberty and bring experienced and thoroughly competent men. I have detailed times for this work as per instructions in office Letters "Land 49554-1908 unclear July 28-1908.

1908
Sept 2 Mrs Gingoldt - with party of 8 pupils enrolled for 3 years and Flormor? Bonga a return pupil 9 in all started for Riggs Inst at Flandreau  S.D. 
The Agent and wife go with party to St. Paul at Agts Expense. visit fair and procure bids for Vault Door also Examine and get prices on Gasoline Engine for Boat reaching agency Saturday 5th Vault wall in Course of Construction. 
8th unclear Mr. Noble visited Agent point Day School site. found school House structure up and shuttered, siding being placed. Outhouses built fortified foundation wall of Employees Cottage about completed each large amount of material on the ground also well dug and partly curbed.

1908
Sept 9 Peter Groves gone to Mum's Mission with party of 6 boys for Indian School -- all for 3 year terms.
Two cars coal delivered at Walker Evening of Sept 5th. Bad Wind and late notice Monday. Got Barge ready and taken across Lake in a rough sea Tuesday. Got it loaded and over to Agency at 8:30 P.M. Tuesday Barge being unloaded this date Should only have been a single car to avoid damage.




1908
Sept 9 Peter Groves gone to Mum's Mission with party of 6 boys for Indian School -- all for 3 year terms.
Two cars coal delivered at Walker Evening of Sept 5th. Bad Wind and late notice Monday. Got Barge ready and taken across Lake in a rough sea Tuesday. Got it loaded and over to Agency at 8:30 P.M. Tuesday Barge being unloaded this date Should only have been a single car to avoid dammage.

190
Nov 28 Orders to Indian trading Post $10.00 for Provisions for Mrs Flatmouth on Auth of July 18 - 1908. This is the first on the $100.00 allowed in Whole or in Trust.
Nov 30 No. bids for Timber.
Nov 30 Stormy with soft snow turning to a blizzard and continued through the night
Dec 1st Agency bay entirely frozen now. Temperature - 8 below 0 at 7 A.M. This is real Winter weather and the first of the season. All furious storms  turning wild.
No mail today.
2 Lake frozen, but unsafe - Mrs. Hammerstrom went to walker by team. Vin Ole agency very Shingobee Bay. -- Made round trip getting in at 9:00 o'clock P.M.

12/7/08 The coldest of the season so far 14° below 0.

   The Indian Woman Nub wu ay goh bu dak goes to the Indigent home of WhIte Earth in care of Mrs. Wm Manypenney - This being the first opportunity since receiving the unclear of May Arrward requesting that she be sent them in the charge of some one.

1909
Dec 12  Saturday morning 12th Nah-bun am we and Frank Ellis called at the agency office and stated that a council was to be held at the old agency and stated that I was asked by the chiefs and head men there assembled to meet with them with Peter Groves as interpreter. That they had requested Hon Daniel DeLury to be present. That the council was important area of great ]]unclear]] to the Indians.  I went as requested and found a very representative body of the Indians present representing the Pillagers, Cass & unclear and W.O.P, of the Mississippi present. They advised me that the purpose of this council was to employ Hon. Danl DeLury as their atty. and to place themselves in a position so they could have their interests guarded by one in whom they had confidence on who

was situated where they could reach him and consult with him and to proceed regularly they appointed by an unanimous rising vote Frank Purshall Chairman of the Council and George Burnette Secy. They then listened to speeches from many of the chiefs and representatives from outer reservations. All arguing that they should wait and act together in harmony for the interest of all concerned. After many had spoken they proposed to Mr. DeLury that he accept the appointment as their atty as a salary of $5000.00 per annum and expenses necessary in visiting Washington word scratched out and authorizing him to pay an atty in Washington if he found it necessary out of his salary. They were evidently agreeably surprised when Mr. DeLury stated that he would not do any thing so long as they recognized? others as their atty

stating that as they had unapproved? contracts with Mr. W.B. Mathews and Daniel B. Hundussen. He did not think it right for him to assume to act as their atty. They confirmed further and by an unanimous rising vote passed a resolution rescinding any former contracts with either of the attorneys named and which had failed of approval by the Indian Department. Mr. DeLury then stated that he would accept the appointment as their atty, at a salary of $3500.00 per annum and boarding expenses should he have to visit Washington and that if he employed an Atty to look after any of their business in Washington he would pay him out of his annual salary of $3500.00. This offer was discussed briefly - being fully explained to the Council and by an unanimous rising

vote was adopted and Mr. DeLury declared to be duly appointed their attorney. And by unanimous rising vote the Chairman and Secretary were Authorized to enter into and sign such contract.

   The Chiefs and head men present declared their full confidence in the agent and their belief in the sincerity of his friendship on his interest in their welfare.  but did want some one employed to act for them who was not subject to the direction of the commissioners of Indian affairs. They asked the line of questions if the Agent was not acting under the directions of the Department which was answered in the affirmative. They asked questions as to how the National Forest Effected the Indian Allotments. Also where the forest 

?patents? so long delayed were

likely to be issued. Stated the needs of many old and extremely poor Indians who were suffering from lack of the commonest necessaries of life and asked if I had any means of providing for them. All of which was answered and fully explained to them.

  They also wanted to know why the school at Sugar Point was not put in operation which was explained and reasons seemed to be satisfactory.

1908
Dec 14 Dr. Wilcox called to attend Miss Fannie Parshall, reported a very badly swollen and painful knee with probable puss or liquid effusion. That owing to the unclear was unwilling to operate for the removal of puss, recommended her being taken to a hospital where it could receive proper attention and care.
15 Dr Wilcox called to see Geo Reed or O-zha-be-e-gaice found him with a well defined case of Pneumonia Also again examined the swollen knee of the girl Fannie Parshall. visited? Mrs Jon Meares and prescribed? for a bad cronic sore on her ankle
17 Visited and prescribed? for Mrs Osborne - cook at the boarding school

1908
12/18 was called to visit two girls at the school.
On this date Frank Parshall took his daughter Fannie to the Hospital at Walker
18 The Police brought in the deserters from the school known as the Brown Eagle girls.
19 The teacher in charge Miss A. Pendergast reported that as soon as the Brown Eagle girls got up they went down the fire escape steps and made a dash for their home and soon after two of the boys word scratched out mounted the school horses and followed locating the girls in a hay stack up near the Cedar point. One of them came in and reported and then police went out and brought them back to the school. The teacher reports them none the worse for their exposure.

1908
12/21 Maud Weaver was in and asked to have Dr. Wilcox called to see her Mother again. The Doctor was consulted and did not think any good would be done by his coming over as he had left plenty of dressing and to do it full justice the sore should be thoroughly cleansed and as Doctor Hardin would be back in a day or two. He would prefer to lt him do for it as it was a chronic sore 
12/21 Geo. Stump was in today having heard that his girls had run off and were nearly frozen. The case was talked over and he stated that he did not want them to  leave school that they were pleased to start in when school commenced and he thought something must have been done to make them want to keep away but they had not told of any thing unclear was advised that this Sept unclear

12/21 did not like to send the police after school children for several reasons. but particularly on account of the appearance of arresting them and its influence in the school with the rest of the schollers.  
1908
12/23 John Taylor wants to put in 40 cord popple [?Green?] wood at the old agency Day school He is to cut in 4 ft and split and pile it back of their out houses. Price $3.00/per cord.
1/12/09 John Lincoln will put 10 cords Birch Norway at old agency 3.00 per cord piled back of buildings & ?Inspected? them

Squaw Point
1908
12/26 Peter Taylor wants to truck in Wood for the Squaw Point Day School and he is authorized to put in 20 Cords of Norway cut & split. 4 ft wood. @ 3:00/per cord delivered and piled at the Day School as directed . Payment to be made as soon as funds for same are available after Wood is inspected 
1/12/09 Wm Butcher wants to put in 20 Cords Wood at Squaw Point day school Same kind & times as Peter Taylor.
1/14/09 James Blaine will cut the other 10 cords to complete the amount.

                          Wm Butcher recommends him

Sugar Point
1909
Jan 1 Nay-sin-nay-way-we-clmay

    Sugar Point wants to put in some Wood at Sugar Point Day School (only 50 cords authorized) $3.00 per cord

May put in all or part

   Can't advance any thing.

1909
Jan 13   Letter to Henry Taylor advising him that complaint is made of his absence from his post and that he fails to do the work unclear by the people.

   Lawrence Roberts will take the place if it is vacated by Henry Taylor.
    Letter to Henry to come to this office - This by Geo. White

1909
Jan 14 Nah-may-poak- an Indian living at the mouth of Warroad River is a friend of C. A. Moody and is given a letter of commendation to Mr. Moody as to his stay on this reservation & visit with his friends.
1/15/09 Frank Purshall arrested evening of 14th inst. by request of his daughter for drunkenness.  Is relieved from the position of Judge of the Court of Indian offenses and May-dway-goh-ro-vind is appointed in his stead this date.
1/25/09 Chas Monroe & Nay-toh-woh-by-tung will put in 50 cords wood to agency at 3.00 per cord

1/28/09 Went to Cass Lake conferred with Dr. Wm H Smith Physician in Chicago
1/29/09 Visited Ball club Public school. found Miss Byrde Hansen in charge. The school is held in the log building belonging to the Indian Dept and formerly used as a Jail. found 3 mixed blood pupils and two whites enrolled and also found that the school had been in operation or session 59 days and that the mixed blood children who lived about 100 rods from the school had attended every day and the whites-- two little girls 6 & 8 of age had only missed 4 Days and had to walk 1½ miles & return.  While the attendance was small the house was well equipped as to seating. Black boards. Books etc. and the teacher is a bright and energetic young lady and the pupils showed intelligence and I am satisfied are making fine progress. As the building is thus used

I am satisfied it is better for the community that it should be used for a public school. Even if the police have to tie a common drunk to a tree until he is sobered. 

   Also learned that there is a public school in the Village of Buna and that to Indian girls, step daughters of a Mr. Gotche are in the school and are said to be progressing very nicely.

3/10/09 In company with J. B. Noble unclear examined school Basement & Laundry building  Found a most dilapidated & Tumble down state of the windows room. Water closet and The work shop in Laundry building open Windows broken. Tool  closet open and tools lying on the floor and bench without any regard to order. Floor covered with dirt & debris. Door into the Laundry had been broken some the casings having been pried out in getting the door off. The closet unclear and the school closet were torn down. Ashes around the furnace door. The railing at one of the front doors down. One front door marked by whittling with a pocket knife and a general lack of oversight on the part of the Management. 

   Intolerable in any government school. Recommendation at once

4/10/09  One of the gray team was badly Corked? while skidding logs early in Feb. and apparently cut into the coffin joint. The animal stood on three legs for several weeks. The farrier unclear poulticed and otherwise treated it believing it would come out well if not entirely sound but the animal begun to show signs of complications and rapidly lost flesh & strength Evidently blood poisoning - resulting in the  beast being unable to use its hind legs so could not get up or stand when assisted to its feet. And as a matter of humanity it was shot to end possible needless suffering.

1904
Apl 12 unclear or Mrs Sam Masters who  belongs? on the White Earth reservation was going to Bear Island with Noh-bish-koh-weh-quod? and at the North End of the Island ran onto thin ice. one side of the sleigh broke the ice and turned both into the cold water before they could be rescued both were greatly exhausted and the women died soon after being taken from the water. Coffin made by agency Carpenters and the Woman buried at the old agency 4/15/09
It is surmised that there was too much booze and that was the probable cause of the accident

4/15/09 Another tragedy to record. on account of too much Whiskey and a blot on some wreches soul for the death of two men- about midnight fire was discovered in the house of Frank Colome or Nay-nah-ah-je-wobe. It was so far advanced that the police and others who went to the House could do nothing. Two Indians were known to have been in the house and were said to have been drunk when they came from Walker late in the afternoon. Those present thought they had probably shorten ? back in Walker for more Whiskey but as the fire progressed it was discovered that they were both in the building and were being cremated. Their names are. Kay-lah-ke-wub-e-lumg? andMay-zhe-day? The first was known as kay-tuck. and was a nephew of the Late chief Flat Mouth. The

4/15/09 Mon. May unclear day was unclear the name of David Wright from the report of their doings from the time they came from Walker, late in the afternoon of the 14th unclear. It seems that they must have been drinking heavily and also have had a good supply in their packs. As they had come in from the sugar camp for supplies and loaded up with boose. David Wright was a bad boozer any time. Kay-tuck. was not so much addicted to liquor. The ones turning of a lamp is the probable cause of the fire and the drunken stupor in which Wright probably was at the time left him a helpless victim. Kay-tuck had evidently tried hard to get out as he was in the kitchen near the Door and being weak lunged. No doubt was easily suffocated  by the smoke and fell before he could make the door.

4/15/09  The police did not notify me as the house was small of hewed Logs with a lean made of Boards and as all was blazing and the men were supposed to have gone to Walker it was past one o'clock before it become known certainly that they were in the building and had been burned to death. The Coronor Dr, Holman of Pine River was notified and said he would be here on the M & I Train arriving at Walker at 4.41 P.M. 

    Dr. Holman of Pine River County Coronor arrived at about 5:30 P.M.  after viewing the remains of the men who lost lost their lives in the burned house, decided that no inquest was necessary particularly so when it was explained that they were under the influence of liquor. It was a clear case of accidental fire either from the stove or more probably by the upsetting of a lamp. In either case its cause was whiskey.

5/14   On acct. of Ice Mail comes only made our round trip leaving in the morning and returning in the evening. He did well to make it once.

5/16/09 Still Agency Lake half covered with broken Ice. Morning. Evening still a border of Ice on south side of the lake and at Piety hill.
5/17/09 Still some Ice on south side.

             On the Lake Walker side Ice in bay and around docks so boats cant get out. On the big lake Ice seems to be still compact from Otter tail to sugar points - as far as can 
             be seen with the glass.

5/18   Mr Kulander brought over 2 tons freight and the Walker & agency ports of Leech Lake are open still apparently solid on big Lake.

          Special Agt Edgar A Allen here

5/19   Ice still looks unclear on big lake
5/20   Still lots of Ice on big Lake
5/21 Still Ice floats in the big Lake off Otter tail Point

1909
5/22  Wah bun rw uee - & others just in from Otter tail point Sugar bush. They report ice still in the Lake and though 76 years of age does not remember the ice to have been so Long. Still ice in big Lake. The Wind usually breaks it up. but this month the wind has been very still.
5/23   It was more windy today and it is believed ice on the big Lake will be extremely broken up and disappear.
The latest on record
5/24   Wah buh kuh nuh gnod and Ko Jemes are just in from Bear Island and they say the Ice is now all gone and in their recollection it has never held so bolt? 
5/27  Indians holding Council. Adjourned to Friday 28 at 1 o'clock - This to Meet Mr Allen Special Agt.

5/27/09 The New government Launch was put in the water and floated at 6 oclock P.M. rode like a duck. Will be known as "Ojib way."
6/3  Visited Bear Island with Edgar A Allen Spec. Agt. used the new Boat had a nice trip. Mr. Allen met a number of Bear Island & Sugar point Indians. All wanted to know the object of his visit and when informed that he was on official visit to accentain Conditions of the people & & report to the Court - said no more.
Put the old team with John Adams on Squaw point to plow gardens for Indians beginnin at the school.

6/5/09 Cool June Morning

Oct 16 Jon Osscar returned from  B....? Island on crossing to N. L. Price Co's camp found the Boat, "Aurok L. there and all safe.   On the trip over the row Boats in tow were swamped and had to be cut loose and were lost.   They belonged to some of the Indian passengers.  
17 Wm Bonga.  a [?Leech?] Lake removal living at the agency Village died at his home this date. of Pneumonia.  He was a good interpreter and had visited Washington on several occasions. He was said to have rendered some valuable service to the Department in the settlement of the trouble arising from the attempted arrest of the old sugar point Indian Preg-o-magashig and which occasioned the [?] of U.S. Soldiers to the reservation and the consequent battle of Sugar Point in which Maj. 1909 Dec 3 Joe Osscan with his little [?launch?] took  Mr. Gingoldt and myself to Walker this afternoon. a pretty rough sea - we got along fairly well. Have to complain only of getting the seat of our trousers wet.   The water froze on our overcoats and did not wet through.  our last boat trip for the season. 
4 Mr Kulander came over in his [?] again today and brought some goods over and also took some of the school unclear over and back. Probably the last boat trip. He is always  doing some kind and generous act for our accommodation.

1909 Dec 8 Mail Messenger arrived on the Ice today also Mr. Poussin walked over

9 The first Pony sleigh crossed and hauled some goods over to the store. Temperature 17º below 0. at day light 

10 Charly Campbell a pupil at the the S.S. school had a leg broken by the [?] of a clothes press in the boys play room.
11 Had the lad taken over to the Hospital at Walker.  The leg having become so swollen.  the Doctor stated it would be necessary to give cholorform and with no one to take care of him I thought best to leave him in the hospital.
13  He is reported doing well.
14  Had another accident at the School Albert Star. while coasting near the [?] in some way ran against something on which a Nail protruded and it tore

14 An ugly wound in his left thigh. With no Physician at hand I ordered him taken at once to the hospital at Walker to have the wound dressed and if necessary have him cared for until it was safe to bring him back to Ute school. 15 - Was over and visited the Hospital.   The boy Charley Hall is doing well and will probably have his leg in a cast in a day or two. The boy Albert Star has an ugly wound hence the Doctor decided it best to keep him for a few days. As it would be necessary to have the wound [?drained?] carefully for several days and the arrangement was agreed to as is was just as cheap for to keep the boy there or to have the Doctor come across the lake to do it.
1904 Dec 20   Dr. F.S. Wilcox reports the boy Albert Star who had the nail wound in thigh as fit to be returned to school and he was accordingly sent for and returned -

1910
Apl 13  Fire appeared to be running north of the Agency and Mr Lei with his men & Team and the entire police force immediately set out for the point, but upon reaching found the fire was another unclear side of the Thomas and as they thought Thomas Boat River. So returned to the Agency.
14  Jon Osscan unclear Barge to Ottawa Trail Point and Brought two Indians from the Sugar Bush with 6 ponies their sleds and Camp Equipage. They reported fire in the unclear timber on the point and I at once sent for the squaw unclear with the police such others Employers as was at hand upon arriving at the Day school. found the fire had unclear quite a large tract but apparently had done very little damage. Possibly may have killed the Pine seedlings but did not destroy

4/14 much of the town center.
Ainon Bonga informed me that the Fire started from a small fire started by Old Chief Koh-Kok-kuw to clean off some rubbish near his house and let it get away before he knew there was any danger. While unclear another ground a light rain fell that put an end to the fire as it was followed by heavy rain 
15  The 15th and by quite a unclear
16  night of 15 and on the 16th - no further trouble is likely in that locallity.

  Marshalland some 15 men were north and ahead of it.
  The Fire was started on sec 4 & sec 26 & 43-31 and ran over a large part of 26, 23, 14 the corner of 13 and into sec 12 probably was over 700 to 900 acres.
  Telegraphed the Def at 14th
  Fire lined out: started in down on square unclear

1910
4/16  "started by old Chief Kak kah-kwi burning rubbish at his place - damage small have employed Indians if necessary to follow border of burned Dist and put out fires in shingles & roofs - if necessary"

 18  Fire entirely out. Ainun Bonga reports it was unnecessary to employ my Indians or others.

1910
4/21    Angeline Martin a prefect in the school died in the dormitory at a few minutes before 10 o'clock P.M. She was 9 years of age, and the first death that has occurred in the school since I have been in charge of the agency. And I am informed it is the first that ever has occurred in the school building. The Doctor was called at 10 or 11 a.m. and found quite a temperature but a normal pulse. prescribed for the child and was again called a few minutes before it died. While he does not diagnose the case fully. it looks like a case of congestion of the Lungs - probably induced by getting in the cold Lake water and running several hours with wet feet the day before she appeared to be sick. It is a matter of extreme angst, but I am unable to find any one to blame. The unclear action unclear when the child unclear.
